sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• must be administered only in combination with the recommended protease inhibitors, ritonavir, and another antiretroviral agent(s)
  • HIV infection: 85 mg ORALLY once daily coadministered with atazanavir 300 mg and ritonavir 100 mg ORALLY once daily; must also be given with another additional antiretroviral agent(s)
  • HIV infection: 85 mg ORALLY once daily coadministered with lopinavir 400 mg and ritonavir 100 mg ORALLY which are given twice daily; must also be given with another additional antiretroviral agent(s)
  • HIV infection: 150 mg ORALLY once daily coadministered with darunavir 600 mg and ritonavir 100 mg ORALLY which are given twice daily; must be given with another additional antiretroviral agent(s)
  • HIV infection: 150 mg ORALLY once daily coadministered with fosamprenavir 700 mg and ritonavir 100 mg ORALLY which are given twice daily; must be given with another additional antiretroviral agent(s)
  • HIV infection: 150 mg ORALLY once daily coadministered with tipranavir 500 mg and ritonavir 200 mg ORALLY which are given twice daily; must be given with another additional antiretroviral agent(s)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy have not been established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: No adjustment required
  • hepatic impairment: No adjustment required in mild (Child-Pugh class A) or moderate (Child-Pugh class B) impairment; use not recommended in severe impairment (Child-Pugh class C)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Hepatic:
  • -- use is not recommended in severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh class C)
  • Immunologic:
  • -- immune reconstitution syndrome may occur, leading to an inflammatory response in patients with indolent or residual opportunistic infections
  • -- autoimmune disorders (eg, Graves disease, polymyositis, Guillain-Barre syndrome) have been reported in the setting of immune reconstitution and may occur many months after initiation of therapy
  • Reproductive:
  • -- breastfeeding; avoid risk of postnatal HIV transmission
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- avoid use with antimycobacterials (ie, rifampin or rifapentine)
  • -- avoid use with hepatitis C virus (HCV) protease inhibitors (ie, telaprevir or boceprevir)
  • -- avoid use with non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (ie, efavirenz or nevirapine)
  • -- avoid use with St. John's wort
  • -- avoid use with medications that contain elvitegravir
  • -- avoid use with a protease inhibitor and cobicistat

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypercholesterolemia (Grade 3 or 4, 5%), Hyperglycemia (Grade 3 or 4, 5%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (7%), Nausea (4%)
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Gamma-glutamyl transferase raised (Grade 3 or 4, 3%), Hypertriglyceridemia (Grade 3 or 4, 5%)
  • Gastrointestinal:High lipase level in serum (Grade 3 or 4, 14%), Serum amylase raised (Grade 3 or 4, 6%)
  • Hematologic:Neutropenia (Grade 3 or 4, 3%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised (Grade 3 or 4, 2%), AST/SGOT level raised (Grade 3 or 4, 2%), Serum bilirubin raised (Grade 3 or 4, 6%)
  • Immunologic:Immune reconstitution syndrome
  • Musculoskeletal:Increased creatine kinase level (Grade 3 or 4, 6%)
  • Psychiatric:At risk for suicide, Suicidal thoughts
  • Renal:Hematuria (Grade 3 or 4, 6%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Elvitegravir is an HIV-1 integrase strand transfer inhibitor. By inhibiting HIV-1 integrase, the HIV virus is unable to integrate viral DNA into the host DNA for viral replication. Elvitegravir does not inhibit human topoisomerases I or II.

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic: primary route via CYP3A and UGT1A1/3
  • Aromatic and aliphatic hydroxylated or glucuronidated metabolites: inactive
  • inducer of CYP2C9 (modest)
  • substrate of CYP3A

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 94.8% unchanged
  • Renal: 6.7% as metabolites
  • Dialyzable: Unlikely (hemodialysis); Unlikely (peritoneal dialysis)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
General Information
  • administer once daily with food
  • must be coadministered with a ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitor; if using with protease inhibitor that is dosed twice daily, administer elvitegravir with the first dose
  • separate antacid use and elvitegravir by at least 2 hours

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Viral load: at baseline and with modification of antiretroviral (ARV) treatment, at 2 to 8 weeks; then every 4 to 8 weeks until values are below the limit of detection (less than 200 copies/mL), then every 3 to 4 months; monitoring may be extended to every 6 months for patients who are immunologically stable, adherent, and with suppressed viral loads for more than 2 years
  • CD4 cell counts: at baseline and with modification of ARV treatment, then every 3 to 6 months during the at least the first 2 years of treatment and if the CD4 counts are below 300 cells/mm(3) or viremia develops; after 2 years monitoring may be extended to every 12 months for patients who are clinically stable with suppressed viral loads
  • Hepatitis B screening: baseline and with modification of ARV treatment; may repeat screening if hepatitis B surface antigen or antibody are negative at baseline.
  • ALT, AST, and total bilirubin; at baseline and with modification of ARV treatment, at 2 to 8 weeks, then every 3 to 6 months
  • Basic chemistry, including serum sodium, potassium, bicarbonate, chloride, BUN, and creatinine; at baseline and with modification of ARV treatment, at 2 to 8 weeks, then every 3 to 6 months
  • CBC with a differential; at baseline and with modification of ARV treatment, then every 3 to 6 months
  • Fasting blood glucose or HbA1c; at baseline and with modification of ARV treatment, then every 3 to 6 months with abnormal values or 12 months with normal values
  • Fasting lipid profile; at baseline and with modification of ARV treatment, at 2 to 8 weeks, then every 6 to 12 months
  • Urinalysis; at baseline or modification of ARV treatment, then annually

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of inflammation or infection.
  • Side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, or headaches.
  • Instruct patient to take drug with food.
